moves.1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd: The Karpov/Smyslov/Steinitz Variation of the Caro-Kann
Black has equalized in the opening.
moves.12... Nd5 13. Bh2 Rc8 14. Ne5 Bxe2 15. Q: Here, Black can capture on d4 and give White an isolated pawn, but then White gets the c-file.
moves.16... Qa5 17. Nd7: This is a dubious move. The knight was well-posted on e5. Now White prepares to exchange this piece.
moves.19... Qxc5 20. Rfd1 h6 21. a3 Qc4 22. Qx: If White tries to win the pinned knight with 23. b3 Rc8 24. c4 Nf6 and the Black rooks defend each other.
moves.23. Rd4 Rdc8 24. Rxc4 Rxc4: Black has a slight advantage in this endgame.
moves.25. Be5: The bishop is heading for d4.
moves.31. Ke2 f5 32. Rf1 g6 33. Kd3 b5 34. b3: Here Black should have played ... Rf6 so that g4 can be met by f4, with a pawn steam-roller on the way.
moves.39... Ke6: White can play g4 here, since ... f4 is no longer possible. If black exchanges pawns with ... fxg4; hxg4 ... Rd3; Re1 Kf5, followed by ... Kg6 and ... h5 creating a passed pawn.
moves.42. a4 Rxe3: Threatening Re2+, winning the g2 pawn
moves.45. Rc2 Ra6 46. Kb3 Rc6: Creating a blockade in front of the white c-pawn.
moves.47. Kb4 a6: This keeps the King out of b5, so White cannot make any progress.
